results.title: Prism of purpose
results.brief_description: Gabo Island - Artist Alexandra Lyall’s paintings of the Gabo Island lighthouse provide haunting visuals to her moving account of the role the lighthouse played in a tragic family history.This work uses digital technology cleverly to allow you to experience Alexandra’s paintings in a new way.

results.title: Drive
results.brief_description: ‘Drive’ takes the watcher on a drive through the bright lights and dark corners of a big city. The animation uses a combination of 3D animation and line drawing to surreal effect giving the work a dreamlike quality - not unlike the experience of driving through the city at night.

results.title: Sailor's dream
results.brief_description: A sailor’s body is marked by experience. As he lies sleeping a sailor remembers incidents from his life – as illustrated by his many tattoos

results.title: Murmur
results.brief_description: Bothered by his heart, a man tries to stifle its incessant beating. At his wit’s end, he abandons his heart in the pouring rain, but in the tradition of Poe the heart is relentless.

results.title: The "A" list
results.brief_description: A charming digital animation from Australia’s premier centre for animation and interactive media ‘ RMIT AIM. Anyone who has tried to get into the ‘cool’ group at school will relate to this tale about jumping from the highest diving board.

results.title: Irati-wanti: the poison leave it
results.brief_description: “All of us were living when the government used the country for the bomb. The Government thought what they knew what they were doing then. We know the poison from the radioactive dump will go down under the ground and leak into the water.” The Kupa Piti Kungka Tjuta, a council of elder Aboriginal women from Coober Pedy, have been campaigning against the Federal Government’s plans to build a national radioactive waste repository on their traditional lands in the South Australian desert. Four years after this documentary was made they are still fighting. A confronting documentary about Australia’s history of Nuclear Testing and its impact on the indigenous inhabitants of so called ‘uninhabited’ land. For more information visit www.irantiwanti.org

results.title: Casterton lights up!
results.brief_description:
Casterton is a small rural town roughly half way between Melbourne and Adelaide, in far western Victoria. Like many smaller rural communities, Casterton has a rich agricultural history that claims not only to being the birthplace of the Kelpie but the first permanent inland Victorian settlement.
Due to a loss of both government and local industries during the nineties, Casterton found itself struggling to maintain its population. In April 1995, a public meeting was called to establish a survival plan. Attended by a hundred or so locals, the meeting produced a number of community initiatives including the developmentof a local phenomenon into a public festival.
In the eight years since, the annual Christmas lights festival has grown into the most important event on Casterton’s social calender. Today, two thirds of all homes in Casterton are lit each Christmas with up to 10,000 visitors passing through the town each December to take part in the nightly lights tours run by the local Lions Club
Casterton Lights Up! is an independently produced community documentary project written, directed, produced and funded by Melbourne Based filmmaker Glen Moore. The project was developed with the assistance and keen support of the Casterton community and aims to highlight the importance of community connectedness and spirit to the survival of small rural communities.

results.title: Loup
results.creator_credit: Northern Metropolitan Institute of TAFE and Kerreen Ely-Harper
results.brief_description:
Loup showcases the talents of the Arts Education dance group students (with disabilities) from NMIT (Northern Melbourne Institute of TAFE). Loup, full of zest and the notion: to dance; to flee; to leap; to burst, lit up the dancers’ desire to devise creative expression in open spaces. In Loup, commemorating the year of the life of the ocean, the dancers, through improvised movements, developed their vision towards a common destination - the sea. Its openness and vastness, power and force depict the energy of freedom that eliminates all barriers. Barriers that may arise from disabilities are suddenly irrelevant.
Loup was filmed at the Jawbone site in the Wetlands in Williamstown. This is a protected conservation area and is used as a metaphor to represent the dancers’ expectation of a safe and open space in which to be, and express freely.
After a decade of regular dance workshops and performances, the artists naturally progressed into a new stage ‘ exploration of dance with media. Creative camera work captured the integrity of their movements. This art form expanded the dimensions of the discipline much practiced by the dancers. At the same time it enabled the documentation of the works thus creating new resources in the field.
Loup, since its production in 1998, has been screened at national and international festivals and community events.

results.title: Stand on your head
results.brief_description:
Stand on your head
This is a film about aging, attitude’and yoga.
Come on a journey to the centre of a suburban yoga class to witness elderly women, some in their nineties, practising yoga. Though they no longer stand on their heads, they do turn society’s perception of the elderly on its head
This film documents how yoga has helped these women keep physically and mentally strong despite their ageing years. The sense of community that coming to the same teacher for over thirty years has given them has also helped them cope with life’s challenges. The film centres on Edka, who maintains that yoga has helped her overcome many tragedies in her life, including the death of her husband and daughter.
By placing a local, multicultural group of ageing women in the spotlight, it is hoped that Stand on your Head can provide a positive role model for other senior citizens.
This ‘no-budget’ film was made in Melbourne by local documentary filmmaker, Naomi Wise. The music featured in the film is an old European Jewish folk tune. Indian instruments are used to reflect the curious mix of cultures in the film. It was arranged by Melbourne music producer Adam Starr and sung in Yiddish by Karen Feldman.

results.title: Seaside searching
results.brief_description:
Seaside Searching consists of interviews with ‘traditional’ local residents about St Kilda and surrounds and how the area is changing, in the context of 100 years history. Speakers include working girls, homeless, welfare workers, and aboriginal residents. While the technical quality is not great, vision and sound are clear.
At first the viewer is not sure where the journey is going, and whether the speakers’ words will be enough to hold our attention given the relative lack of visual stimulation. However as the program continues we are drawn in and held by the honesty, openness and truth of what we hear. The exterior interview locations grow on the viewer as markers of place. We realise that these uneducated or unsophisticated voices are saying important and meaningful things about community, change, class and status, and how regional social change affects the individual. By the close, one likes and believes in these ‘ordinary people’, and learns the value of community voices irrespective of their apparent form.
